us.pecon.ray.chessPlay

Class ChessBoard

  • java.lang.Object
    • us.pecon.ray.chessPlay.ChessBoard
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ChessBoard_ai

    public class ChessBoard
extends java.lang.Object
    A class representing a chess board in which individual pieces will be placed and manipulated upon. Its primary method of manipulation and containment is a matrix array containing individual Piece classes, which can be moved around with either human readable or machine friendly commands.
    Author:
    Ethan Arns

    • Constructor Detail

      • ChessBoard

        public ChessBoard()
        Chess board class constructor. Sets current turn to white and initiates the two other variables blank

    • Method Detail

      • setDebug

        public void setDebug(boolean which)
        Sets debug mode. If on, System will print messages showing moves, errors, and board states.
        Parameters:
        which - true to set debug mode on, false to disable debug mode

      • isDebug

        public boolean isDebug()
        Getter for debug mode.
        Returns:
        true if debug mode is on

      • help_console

        public void help_console()
        A simple function for providing info to the players. Prints out a lot of text via System.out, so won't work if only GUI is available.

      • isGameOver

        public boolean isGameOver()
        A getter used to see if the game should end.
        Returns:
        boolean of whether or not to end the game

      • getTurn

        public java.lang.String getTurn()
        Returns the current turn as a String
        Returns:
        a string representing the turn

      • changeTurn

        public void changeTurn()
        Changes the turn to the opposite of what it currently is. If turn is invalid, it set it to White.

      • getPiece

        public Piece getPiece(int x,
                      int y)
        Retrieves piece at coordinate location
        Parameters:
        x - the x coordinate
        y - the y coordinate
        Returns:
        piece the Piece at the location specified, null if invalid

      • getPiece

        public Piece getPiece(Position pos)
        Retrieves piece at Position class location
        Parameters:
        pos - the position object to retrieve located piece
        Returns:
        piece found, else returns null

      • printBoardState

        public void printBoardState()
        Prints the board to Console output in ASCII format

      • printBoardState_hr

        public void printBoardState_hr()
        Prints the board to Console output in ASCII format, but in a more human readable and official way

        public void placePiece(Piece piece)
        Places a new piece on the ChessBoard

                       Position pos)
        Place a piece on the ChessBoard, adjusted with Position object
        Parameters:
        piece - piece to place
        pos - location to place piece

      • placePiece

        public void placePiece(Piece piece,
                       int x,
                       int y)
        Place a piece on the ChessBoard, adjusted with coordinates
        Parameters:
        piece - the piece object to be placed
        x - the x coordinate
        y - the y coordinate

      • resetBoard

        public void resetBoard()
        Places all pieces in proper starting position

      • move

        public boolean move(Piece p,
                    int x,
                    int y)
        Moves a piece by advancing it according to the offset specified by x and y parameters. Also determines capture. Returns true if successful.
        Parameters:
        p - the piece selected to be moved
        x - how far left or right to move
        y - how far up or down to move
        Returns:
        true if move was successful, false if not

      • textToPosition

        public Position textToPosition(java.lang.String input)
        Takes in a 2 character string (not including trimmed spaces) and converts them to a Position object representing the string's intended position. Case insensitive.
        Example: user inputs "A4". Returns Position object with x of 0 and y of 5.
        Parameters:
        input - String representing position in algebraic notation
        Returns:
        Position the string represents, null if error

      • move_hr

        public boolean move_hr(java.lang.String move)
        This is a separate version of move(), which instead of raw information, takes in a String that is hopefully algebraic notation and will then translate that to computer-friendly movement. It must check if the notation is correct first, and will return false if not. Makes liberal use of input checking, because users cannot be trusted.
        Parameters:
        move - the string that will relay the movement
        Returns:
        true if successful, false if error

      • showCaptured

        public void showCaptured()
        Prints to console a list of captured pieces
